ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: it was mostly fluff
Social construction, normativity, institutions, social coordination, money, ownership, human kinds, social + institutional roles, power, the Ameliorative Project.
I am now able to look at the world with a completely new perspective. I can analyze
Thinking more deeply about the world around me and questioning what I know about social constructs.
I had fantastic conversations and considered the effects of social construction on society.
I gained a much greater understanding of some of the philosophical underpinnings of a lot of psychological theories I had previously learned.

I learned a new way to approach my daily life, taking notice of the social constructions around me. I also learned how to think more deeply about research studies, paying attention to aspects that could be improved, etc.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
strengths: really nice prof
weaknesses: we got off topic a lot, we ran out of time, conversation often went nowhere and was very fluffy
Very good class!

I really liked the way the course was structured, and I thought the student presentations were a great way to engage with the material. The topics were all relevant and interesting, and maybe the only improvement would be to talk a bit more about experimental topics, or ones for which there aren't many established answers yet.
The professor was really nice and helpful in the class. I think the class would benefit from a little bit more structure.
I would have liked more variation in structure - there were a lot of presentations which would have been nice to have been broken up.
I thought the readings for this course were all very interesting and engaging, and none of them felt too "dense" or boring. I also liked the balance between discussion and lecture in the classroom.

Strengths - helps students approach concepts in a new way, shows that even if its a published research study there are still components that challenge the validity, course allows students freedom within the topics to explore their interests

Weaknesses - maybe some more class discussion balanced with lecture & presentation could be good

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: yes, this was a great class! I learned so much about social construction and I notice themes of this course in real life almost every day.

nah, if you're looking for a seminar that covers this I'd go for one that has a more rigorous discussion. Every week people would critique the same things about the studies. Dr. Dunham is really nice but we would run out of time a lot or we would get off topi a lot.
Yes, great class and great conversations!
Yes, I believe any student in psychology, cognitive science, or related fields would benefit from this course.
Yes, Professor Dunham is a really nice professor and the material is very engaging (especially as you go further into the semester)
Yes! Especially with Prof. Dunham.

Yes, I would! Professor Dunham is so kind and engaged in the course and clearly wants his students to learn and succeed. The class is not only interesting but also will force you to challenge previously held beliefs.
Yes! Its an interesting course.
